hints.content:
Partial products help us multiply larger numbers.

We can break the first factor apart by place value and multiply the parts *in any order* by the parts of the second factor. Then we add those products to get the final product.

[[☃ explanation 1]]

Let's take a look at how Nick broke apart the numbers to multiply.

options.explanation:
$54\times 26$

We can break apart $54$ into $50 + 4$ and break apart $26$ into $20+6$.

[[☃ image 1]]

We can start by multiplying $50\times 20$ , $50\times 6$, $4\times 20$ or $4\times6 $. The order does not matter since we will be adding all the products together.

$\begin{array}{rr}
&\begin{align}
54&\\
\underline{{} \times 26}\end{align}\\
\text{any order}&\left\{\begin{align}
1{,}000\\
300\\
80\\
\underline{{}+24}\end{align}\right.\\
&\begin{align}
1{,}404
\end{align}
\end{array}$
options.showPrompt: Can you show me an example please?

options.alt: A rectangular array split in 4 parts. The top left part has a height of 6 and a base of 50. The top right part has a height of 6 and a base of 4. The bottom left part has a height of 20 and a base of 50. The bottom right part has a height of 20 and a base of 4. The left side of the array is labeled 6 plus 20. The bottom of the array is labeled 50 plus 4.

hints.content:
###Step $1$

$\begin{align}
\goldE{4}2&\\
\underline{{} \times \goldE{3}6}&\\
\goldE{1{,}200}&\quad \goldE{30} \times \goldE{40}
\end{align}$

There are $3$ tens in $36$, and there are $4$ tens in $42$.  Also,
$\goldE{30}\times\goldE{40}=\goldE{1{,}200}$, so Nick did not make a mistake in step $1$.

###Step $2$

$\begin{align}
4\maroonE{2}&\\
\underline{{} \times \maroonE3{6}}&\\
{1{,}200}&\quad {30} \times{40} \\
{\maroonE{60}}&\quad {\maroonE{30}} \times\maroonE{2} \\
\end{align}$

Nick said the value of the $2$ in $4\maroonE{2}$ is $2\text{ tens}$, not $\maroonE{2\text{ ones}}$, so Nick made a mistake in step $2$.
Nick made a mistake in step $2$.

question.content:
Nick tried to evaluate $42\times36$ using partial products, but he made a mistake.  His work is below.

$\begin{array}{llrr}
&&42 \\
&&\underline{{}\times36} \\
&\goldE{\text{Step 1}}&\goldE{ 1{,}200}& \goldE{30\times 40}\\
&\maroonE{\text{Step 2}}&\maroonE{600}& \maroonE{30\times 20}\\
&\tealE{\text{Step 3}}&\tealE{240}& \tealE{6\times 40}\\
&\blueE{\text{Step 4}}&\underline{{}+\blueE{12}}& \blueE{6\times2}\\
&\purpleE{\text{Step 5}}&\purpleE{2{,}052}&
 \end{array}$

**Find Nick's mistake.**

[[☃ radio 2]]

choices.clue:
There are $3$ tens in $36$, and there are $4$ tens in $42$.  Also,
$\goldE{30}\times\goldE{40}=\goldE{1{,}200}$, so Nick did not make a mistake in step $1$.
There are $2$ ones, not $2$ tens, in $42$. So Nick made a mistake in step $2$.

There are $6$ ones in $36$, and there are $4$ tens in $42$.  Also,
$\tealE{6}\times\tealE{40}=\tealE{240}$, so Nick did not make a mistake in step $3$.

There are $6$ ones in $36$, and there are $2$ ones in $42$.  Also,
$\blueE{6}\times\blueE{2}=\blueE{12}$, so Nick did not make a mistake in step $4$.
Nick correctly added his four partial products.
